thread.title: Trump says new security announcement expected next week
thread.title_full: Trump says new security announcement expected next week - The Boston Globe

title: Trump says new security announcement expected next week
text:
Mario Tama/Getty Images
President Donald Trump (right) held a joint press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at the White House Friday.
By Martin Finucane Globe Staff February 10, 2017
President Donald J. Trump said Friday that sometime next week he will announce measures to increase national security. He did not say what they were.
“We’ll be doing something very rapidly having to do with additional security for our country. You’ll be seeing that sometime next week,” Trump said at a joint press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
Advertisement
Trump’s comments came after an NBC News report that his administration is rewriting his controversial travel ban so it could pass legal muster. Trump has painted the travel ban as necessary to keep the country safe, but it is tied up in the courts.
He also said at the press conference that his administration would continue the legal battle to get the travel ban reinstated.
Get Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here “In addition, we will continue to go through the court process, and ultimately I have no doubt that we’ll win that particular case,” he said.
A San Francisco-based U.S. appeals court on Thursday refused to reinstate his temporary ban on travel to the United States by refugees and residents of seven mostly Muslim countries in the name of national security.
Trump said there were “tremendous threats to our country” but he felt “totally confident that we will have tremendous security for the people of the United States.”
Advertisement
“We will be doing things to continue to make our country safe,” he said. “It will happen rapidly and we will not allow people into our country who are looking to do harm to our people.”
Material from The Associated Press was used in this report.
